LESS: Selecting Influential Data for Targeted Instruction Tuning
Mengzhou Xia1 *Sadhika Malladi1 *Suchin Gururangan2Sanjeev Arora1Danqi Chen1
Abstract
Instruction tuning has unlocked powerful capabili-
ties in large language models (LLMs), using com-
bined datasets to develop general-purpose chat-
bots. However, real-world applications often re-
quire a specialized suite of skills (e.g., reasoning).
The challenge lies in identifying the most relevant
data from these extensive datasets to effectively
develop specific capabilities, a setting we frame
astargeted instruction tuning . We propose LESS,
an optimizer-aware and practically efficient al-
gorithm to estimate data influences and perform
Low-rank gradi EntSimilarity Search for instruc-
tion data selection. Crucially, LESS adapts exist-
ing influence formulations to work with the Adam
optimizer and variable-length instruction data.
LESS first constructs a highly reusable and trans-
ferable gradient datastore with low-dimensional
gradient features and then selects examples based
on their similarity to few-shot examples embody-
ing a specific capability. Experiments show that
training on a LESS-selected 5% of the data can of-
ten outperform training on the full dataset across
diverse downstream tasks. Furthermore, the se-
lected data is highly transferable: smaller models
can be leveraged to select useful data for larger
models and models from different families. Our
qualitative analysis shows that our method goes
beyond surface form cues to identify data that ex-
emplifies the necessary reasoning skills for the
intended downstream application. To facilitate fu-
ture work, we release code and data at princeton-
nlp/LESS.

the author(s).1. Introduction
Instruction tuning has made large language models (LLMs)
adept at following human instructions (Ouyang et al., 2022)
as versatile chatbots (OpenAI, 2022; 2023; Anthropic, 2023;
Google, 2023). Recent efforts curating highly diverse and
wide-ranging instruction tuning datasets (Taori et al., 2023;
Wang et al.; Mukherjee et al., 2023; Xu et al., 2023, inter
alia) induce remarkably strong generalization even from a
small number of examples (Zhou et al., 2023). Regardless,
it remains an open problem to understand how to best utilize
these various datasets.
Many real-world applications call for cultivating a specific
suite of capabilities in LLMs (e.g., reasoning skills). How-
ever, training LLMs with mixed instruction tuning datasets
can hinder the development of these specific capabilities.
For example, Wang et al. (2023b) demonstrates that LLMs
trained on a mix of instruction tuning datasets exhibit worse
performance than those trained on a subset of the data. Ad-
ditionally, considering the broad spectrum of user queries
and the multitude of skills required to respond to them,
there may not always be enough in-domain data available.
Therefore, we hope to be able to effectively use the general
instruction tuning data to improve specific capabilities. We
frame this setting as targeted instruction tuning :
Given just a handful of examples embodying a specific
capability, how can we effectively select relevant fine-tuning
data from a large collection of instruction datasets?
We approach this problem by prioritizing training on data
that directly minimizes loss on a target task instead of re-
lying on surface form features (Gururangan et al., 2020;
Xie et al., 2023b). Inspired by past works estimating the
influence of individual training datapoints with gradient in-
formation (Pruthi et al., 2020; Han et al., 2023), we design
an optimizer-aware approach to select such data. How-
ever, straightforward application of this influence formula-
tion faces several challenges unique to the instruction tun-
ing setting: (1) LLMs are traditionally fine-tuned with the
Adam optimizer (Kingma & Ba, 2015) instead of the canon-
ical SGD optimizer; (2) using sequence-level gradients of
variable-length instruction data can derail the influence es-
timation; and (3) the large number of trainable parameters
in LLMs makes the computation and storage of gradient
information extremely resource-intensive.

We address these concerns in LESS, an algorithm that per-
forms Low-rank gradi EntSimilarity Search to select rele-
vant instruction tuning data for a target application, which
exhibits the following properties:
1.Compatible with instruction tuning with Adam ( §2
and§3): LESS adapts the gradient features from clas-
sical influence formulations (Pruthi et al., 2020) to
work with the Adam optimizer and variable-length in-
struction data. The optimization insights and influence
formulation may be of independent interest as well.
2.Efficient ( §4.1): LESS uses LoRA (Hu et al., 2021)
and random projections (Johnson & Lindenstrauss,
1984) to construct a gradient datastore with low-
dimensional, easily manipulable gradient features that
permit efficient and effective dataset selection. The
gradient datastore can be reused for new target tasks.
3.Transferable ( §5.3): Data selected using small models’
gradient features induce strong performance in large
models and models from different families, adding to
the efficiency of LESS (Table 2).
4.Interpretable ( §6.2): Qualitative analysis shows that
LESS selects data with similar reasoning and skill
types as the target task, whereas existing approaches
often select data based on surface form cues (e.g., lan-
guage or topic).
We evaluate our approach on three diverse down-
stream datasets— MMLU (Hendrycks et al., 2020), TY-
DIQA (Clark et al., 2020), and BBH (Suzgun et al.,
2023)—each containing distinct subtasks that effectively
simulate targeted instruction tuning scenarios. Results show
that LESS often selects a small subset of the data ( 5%) that
outperforms training on the full dataset, and the selected
subset remains universally effective across model scales and
families (Table 2). Comparisons with other data selection
methods show that LESS is the only consistently effective
approach, justifying its relatively high computational cost.

3. LESS: Estimating the Influence of
Instructions
Here, we describe how LESS adapts the influence formu-
lation in Equation (1) to select instructions that effectively
induce a target capability. We consider two main conceptual
challenges here: (1) past works described in Section 2 focus
on the SGD optimizer, but LLMs are traditionally tuned
using Adam ( §3.1), and (2) instruction tuning exhibits ab-
normal gradients that cause the prior formulation to heavily
favor selecting shorter instructions, thereby hurting perfor-
mance (§3.2).

3.2. Addressing Abnormalities in Sequence-Level
Gradients
A faithful application of Section 2 to the instruction tuning
setting would consider that the gradient of an example zis
the average of the gradients of each token in the completion.
In particular, we would choose which tokens to train on
within each sequence in order to best reduce the validation
loss, and notably, optimizing the inner product at a fine-
grained level may lead to better results. However, estimating
individual token influences is extremely expensive because
it requires computing the gradient of a vector of token losses
with respect to the model parameters, so we instead perform
data selection at the sequence level.

4. LESS: Estimating Influences Efficiently
We have established how to estimate the influence using
model gradients, but given the sheer size of LLMs, com-
puting and storing model gradients is still prohibitively ex-
pensive. In this section, we describe the design choices
that make LESS computationally efficient, and illustrate the
computing steps in Figure 1.
We use LoRA (Hu et al., 2021) to efficiently perform the
warmup training. Then, we construct a gradient datastore
of projected low-dimensional gradient features (Johnson &
Lindenstrauss, 1984; Park et al., 2023) that can be reused
for different target tasks. Finally, we detail how our data
selection algorithm uses the datastore to construct a training
dataset that accommodates substructures (e.g., individual
reasoning skills) in the target validation set.

4.1. Efficient Gradient Feature Computation
Computing Definition 3.1 requires taking the inner prod-
uct of two vectors with a size of trainable parameters in
the model. Directly using such high-dimensional gradient
vectors as features for dataset selection is very computa-
tionally expensive, so we apply two techniques to construct
meaningful low-dimensional gradient features: parameter
efficient fine-tuning via LoRA (Hu et al., 2021) and random
projections (Johnson & Lindenstrauss, 1984; Park et al.,
2023). We apply these techniques to ∇ℓ(z′;θ)for valida-
tion datapoints z′and to Γ(z,θ)for training datapoints z.
To enable rapid transfer to new target validation tasks, we
create a datastore with these low-dimensional features for
candidate training datapoints.

5. Experiments
We introduce the experimental setup ( §5.1) and relevant
baselines ( §5.2), and then we present the main results ( §5.3).

5.2. Baselines
We compare LESS with a several baselines (see more details
in Appendix C). The simplest baseline is random selection ,
where we randomly sample data from the training set for
instruction tuning. We also compare to BM25 (Robert-

frequency statistics (i.e., TF-IDF) to rank the training in-
stances, and select the top kdata points with the highest
scores to construct Dtrain. Another baseline is DSIR (

6.2. Qualitative Analysis
We manually compare the data selected by LESS and base-
line approaches. Table 16 shows top examples selected by
BM25, RDS, and LESS, given a single Bengali question-
answering example from the TYDIQAdataset. BM25 and
RDS simply match the few-shot data Dvaland select Ben-
gali examples from different tasks (mask recovery and hate
speech detection, respectively).10In contrast, LESS selects
an English example from an open-book question-answering
task similar to TYDIQA. This example demonstrates that
LESS selects examples with a similar underlying reasoning
type without relying heavily on surface textual or linguis-
tic cues. Such examples enable effective zero-shot transfer
to the Bengali language, despite being in a different lan-
guage (Hu et al., 2020). Furthermore, we observe that LESS
chooses more examples from the DOLLY dataset for TY-
DIQA, likely because DOLLY contains many open-book
question-answering examples. Our findings suggest that
LESS may be used to improve interpretability of large,
general-purpose instruction tuning datasets. Appendix K
contains more analysis details.
7. Related Work
Curating high-quality instruction tuning data. Using
high-quality instruction tuning data can dramatically im-
prove base LLMs. Instruction tuning data is generally of
two types: (1) task-based datasets curated from traditional
NLP tasks (Wang et al., 2022; Sanh et al., 2022; Wei et al.,
10The top 10 examples selected by BM25 and RDS are of Ben-
gali translation, Bengali sentiment classification, Bengali mask
prediction, etc.2022b; Longpre et al., 2023), and (2) open-ended instruc-
tion following datasets, broadly covering a wide range of
topics (Taori et al., 2023; Conover et al., 2023; K ¨opf et al.,
2023; Xu et al., 2023; Mukherjee et al., 2023; Zhou et al.,
2023; Ding et al., 2023). Increasing data quality and diver-
sity instead of quantity has been shown to more effectively
induce instruction following abilities (Cao et al., 2023; Chen
et al., 2023a; Bukharin & Zhao, 2023; Du et al., 2023; Liu
et al., 2023; Li et al., 2023). Moreover, (Han, 2023; Lin
et al., 2023a) have demonstrated that in-context learning
alone can significantly advance instruction following. Our
work adds to this narrative by selecting high-quality, rele-
vant data from a large pool of available datasets to induce a
particular capability in the model.
Coresets and gradient-based data selection. Data selec-
tion has been viewed as a coreset selection problem (Phillips,
2017), which aims to find a subset of training examples
that induces performance similar to training on the full
dataset (Toneva et al., 2018; Sener & Savarese, 2018; Cole-
man et al., 2019; Kaushal et al., 2019; Xia et al., 2020;
Mirzasoleiman et al., 2020; Feldman & Zhang, 2020; Kil-
lamsetty et al., 2021a;b; Paul et al., 2021; Meding et al.,
2021; Mindermann et al., 2022; Sors

et al., 2023). These works focus on in-domain coreset selec-
tion, whereas our work involves transfer learning. Several
prior works use pre-defined notions of useful data (Gururan-
gan et al., 2020; Chen et al., 2023b) or n-gram features (Xie
et al., 2023b) to select pre-training examples, but LESS
more closely resembles Mirzasoleiman et al. (2020); Wang
et al. (2020); Yu et al. (2020b); Killamsetty et al. (2021a) in
its reliance on gradient information. Our work is closest to
Han et al. (2023), which used model gradients to select pre-
training data to improve in-context learning performance.
However, our offline approach enables extremely efficient
adaptation to new downstream tasks.
Data attribution and influence functions. Our formula-
tion of influence has been used in identifying mislabeled
examples (Pruthi et al., 2020), analyzing memorization ef-
fects (Feldman & Zhang, 2020), and deriving various inter-
pretability insights (Madsen et al., 2022), but it does not per-
mit counterfactual reasoning. On the other hand, influence
functions (Hampel, 1974) can counterfactually reason about
model behaviors and training data (Koh & Liang, 2017), but
some studies have found limitations (Bae et al., 2022) in
its robustness (Basu et al., 2020) and effectiveness (Ilyas
et al., 2022). In the LLM setting, influence functions are
computationally expensive (Grosse et al., 2023), though
concurrent work in Engstrom et al. (2024) proposed using
an efficient influence function estimation (Park et al., 2023)
to select pre-training data (see Appendix G for a detailed
comparison of influence functions and our influence for-
mulation). Our findings suggest that first-order influence

8. Discussion and Future Work
We propose a data selection algorithm LESS based on
optimizer-aware influences ( §2 and §3). LESS creates a
datastore of effective and reusable low-dimensional gradient
features to enable efficient data selection ( §4). Experiments
in§5 demonstrate the effectiveness of LESS compared to rel-
evant baselines and also highlight the ability to use smaller
models to select data to train larger models (Table 2). Anal-
ysis and ablations in §6 demonstrate that our method selects
more interpretable data but can be computationally expen-
sive. We discuss the limitations in detail in Section 8.
In the future, LESS could be effectively used for test-time
adaptation, allowing the model to adapt on data selected
based on the context and demonstrations provided by the
users. Additionally, we could modify the data selection
procedure to minimize anydifferentiable metric (e.g., a
surrogate for toxicity and harmfulness) instead of just cross-
entropy loss. Moreover, our experiments and concurrent
findings in Engstrom et al. (2024) may prompt further in-
vestigation of the utility of gradient features as opposed to
surface-form cues in data selection. Insights into the opti-
mization characteristics and sequence-level gradient phe-
nomena (§3.2) are likely of theoretical interest.
Our observation that tuning on more data can degrade per-
formance on a particular task may also be intimately con-
nected to the catastrophic forgetting behaviors observed in
LLMs (Lin et al., 2023b).
Limitations
We discuss the limitations of our approach here.
1.Warmup training phase is required. The warmup
training phase is crucial for obtaining useful gradi-
ent features for data selection. It is evident that we
must fine-tune the base model to align with the spe-
cific data distribution we intend to select from, because
directly utilizing gradients from pre-trained models
likeLLAMA -2-7B orLLAMA -2-7B-C HAT is not as
effective (Table 5). This additional step introduces
increased complexity and computational load to LESS.
2.Average gradients over completion tokens. The av-
erage gradient of all the completion tokens is used as a
surrogate to represent the entire sequence.In scenarios
involving longer sequences in training or validation
data, such as open-ended

generation, this aggregation
could become more ambiguous and less effective. In
Section 3.2, we highlight how this operation can cause
anomalies in the data selection pipeline.3.Minimizing loss does not monotonically increase
performance. Unlike standard vision settings, mini-
mizing the validation loss (i.e., cross entropy loss) does
not always improve the task performance in instruc-
tion tuning. This is because instruction tuning tasks
can generally require the model to produce long-form
generations. Although perplexity aligns well with task
performance in base LLMs (Xia et al.), but the rela-
tionship is much more obscure in fine-tuning tuning or
instruction tuning (Tay et al., 2021; Zhou et al., 2023).
LESS is motivated by selecting datapoints that mini-
mize the validation loss (Section 2) and this strategy
often induces models with high accuracy (Table 2),
but minimizing loss does not monotonically improve
accuracy (see our discussion in Appendix I).
4.Linearity in data selection. The first-order approxima-
tion in Section 2 ignores the effect of adding multiple
datapoints together. In particular, two duplicate points
would be scored equally highly and thought to doubly
improve the model, though this is likely not the case.
Preliminary theory in Saunshi et al. (2023) discusses
when influences may add linearly. However, several
more sophisticated algorithms have been proposed to
more flexibly model interactions across datapoints at a
significantly higher computational cost (Søgaard et al.,
2021; Guu et al., 2023). Unfortunately, such algorithms
are too expensive in the language model setting.

A. Training
A.1. Training Datasets
For training, we utilize the same four processed datasets as referenced in (Wang et al., 2023b). Each of these datasets
is either annotated or authored by humans. Further details about these datasets can be found in Table 7. The FLAN V2
andCOTdatasets are derived from existing NLP datasets, while DOLLY andOPEN ASSISTANT 1consist of open-ended
generation examples featuring answers written by humans. These datasets vary significantly in format, sequence length, and
underlying tasks, reflecting the heterogeneity of instruction-tuning datasets. We adopt the following ’Tulu’ format from the
study by Wang et al. (2023b) to standardize the format of these datasets.

A.2. Training Details
All experiments were conducted using the parameter-efficient fine-tuning method LoRA (Hu et al., 2021). We employed a
learning rate scheduler with linear warm-up and cosine decay, reaching a peak learning rate of 2×10−5. A batch size of
128 was used, and training was carried out for 4 epochs across all selected datasets. We initially conducted experiments to
align the number of training steps between small and large datasets. However, increasing the number of epochs on small
datasets did not yield performance improvements. Consequently, we opted for a fixed number of epochs in all experiments.
For the LoRA module, we specified a rank of 128, an αvalue of 512, a dropout rate of 0.1, and learned LoRA matrices
for all attention matrices. This configuration resulted in 135 million trainable parameters for LLAMA -2-7B , constituting
1.95% of the original LLAMA -2-7B model. For MISTRAL -7B, there were 109 million trainable parameters, accounting for
1.48% of the original MISTRAL -7Bmodel. Lastly, the LLAMA -2-13B model comprised 209 million trainable parameters,
representing 1.59% of the original L LAMA -2-13B model.
In each experiment, we performed three trials using distinct random seeds. When employing random selection approaches,
this entailed selecting three different random subsets from the training dataset. In the case of our approach (LESS), it
involved conducting warmup training with various subsets of the training data and subsequently selecting different subsets
for each trial from each warmup-trained model. We used consistent optimization seeds across all experiments.
B. Evaluation Details
We follow Wang et al. (2023b) to evaluate the performance of the models on the target tasks. For MMLU , we measure the
5-shot accuracy of the test set averaged across 57 subtasks. For TYDIQA, we measure the 1-shot macro-averaged F1 score
across all 11 languages. We adopt the gold-passage setup where one passage containing the reference answer is provided
to the model. For BBH , we report the average 3-shot exact match score across all tasks. Chain-of-thought reasoning is
provided in each in-context learning example to prompt the model to generate chain-of-thought reasoning traces for test
examples. We evaluate on the validation set Dval(the same reference set used for data selection) at the end of each epoch
and select the best checkpoint to evaluate on the final test set for each experiment. Note that this procedure might introduce
some bias to the final test set, given that the validation set is relatively small (e.g

C. Baseline Details
For baseline approaches that involve stochasticity (i.e., all except BM25), we perform three runs with different random seeds
and report the average performance and standard deviation.
C.1. BM25
We implement the BM25 baseline with the rank bm2511package. We employ the same approach to aggregating scores
across subtasks as Equation (2), except using the BM25 scores instead of the gradient similarity scores.
C.2. DSIR
DSIR (Xie et al., 2023b) offers a lightweight approach to select data based on specific target distributions using n-gram
features. However, we find it unsuitable for our specific setting. The primary issue stems from the difficulty in learning
a reliable n-gram model with the limited data available in our target distribution, leading to a sparse n-gram table. We
hypothesize that this sparsity arises from the trade-off between bucket size and estimation accuracy for the source and
target distribution: larger buckets result in a highly sparse table with unreliable estimations for data selection, while smaller
buckets lead to more hash collisions for the data in the source distribution. In our empirical observations, we noticed that
DSIR tends to prefer shorter sequences, which can harm performance (see Table 13 for similar evidence). The tendency of
DSIR to select short sequences is also mentioned in Appendix J of Xie et al. (2023b), where the authors impose heuristic
quality filters on top of the DSIR-selected datasets.

D.1. Comparing SGD and Adam Optimizers for Instruction Tuning
The Adam optimizer (Kingma & Ba, 2015) is commonly employed for fine-tuning large language models. However, SGD is
a more desirable optimizer due to its lower memory usage; moreover, the influence formulation we introduce in §2 applies
only to SGD. Here, we verify that using SGD to instruction tune models results in markedly worse performance Table 8.
Our findings consistently demonstrate that using the Adam optimizer yields better results across all three datasets. This
validates the widespread practice of utilizing the Adam optimizer for fine-tuning large language models.

D.2. Selecting Data for SGD, SignGD, and Adam Gradients
In order to compute the influence when training with the Adam optimizer (Definition 3.1), we need to access the Adam

and thus essentially perform coordinate-wise normalization on the gradient. Later empirical and theoretical in Malladi
et al. (2023) suggested that fine-tuning language models occurs in the early stages of Adam, so signGD may be a decent
approximation of fine-tuning LLMs with the Adam optimizer.
In the current paper, we obtain Γthrough the optimizer states computed over the course of a short warmup training period.

E. Nuances in Algorithm Design
In Sections 2 and 3, we outline how first-order approximations of influence functions can be used to design optimizer-
aware data selection algorithms. Here, we discuss some of the nuances in designing such an algorithm for the practical
hyperparameter settings used in instruction tuning.
Batch Size. The per-step influence and trajectory-wise influence of a training datapoint zon a validation datapoint z′is
characterized under the assumption that the batch size is 1. Standard training setups use a larger batch size, but it is difficult
to characterize how training on a batch of examples can change ℓ(z′;θ). However, under the assumption that the first-order
approximation is sufficiently powerful to describe training dynamics, we can directly use the linearity of the gradient to
derive the influence of a single datapoint within a batch. In particular, when training with SGD on a batch Btof size B, we

The design of LESS relies on the assumption that the first-order approximation of loss dynamics is sufficiently accurate
(see Section 2). A related hypothesis is the idea that the instruction tuning optimization procedure exhibits “kernel

behavior”.12Here, we highlight the nuanced difference between kernel behavior and the current assumption, emphasizing
why kernel behavior is difficult to measure in the instruction tuning setting.
Formal Difference Kernel behavior describes the gradient of the output of the model (i.e., the logits) with respect to the
model parameters. In contrast, the first-order approximation in Section 2 is for the gradient of the losswith respect to the
parameters. These two quantities are related by the derivative of the loss with respect to the output of the model. Thus,
conceptually, kernel behavior and the first-order approximation of the loss dynamics are similar, but the two phenomena
correspond to different formal descriptions of model training. Theory in Yang & Hu (2021); Malladi et al. (2023) indicates
that there is some subtlety in whether one phenomenon implies the other holds. In particular, most kernel-based analyses
minimize the mean squared error loss instead of the cross-entropy loss, the latter of which introduces technical complications
in the analysis but is the standard choice for instruction tuning.
F.1. Does instruction tuning exhibit kernel behavior?
Malladi et al. (2023) suggested that fine-tuning on GLUE-style classification tasks can sometimes exhibit kernel behavior
because the pre-trained model is already fairly strong at the downstream task. This assumption crucially relied on appending
a very good prompt to the downstream task input, so that labeling the input amounted to predicting the next word. With
such a prompt, fine-tuning on the downstream task amounted to the same as continued pre-training. One could argue that
the instruction in instruction tuning provides a prompt for the completion, but the completion can be much longer than the
single-word labels used in classification tasks.
Gradient features change substantially at the start of instruction tuning. We perform ablations comparing gradient
features collected from the pre-trained model and features collected over the course of the warmup training period (Table 6).
We find that it is important to incorporate gradients taken over the course of the warmup training, which suggests that the
gradient features change substantially at the start of instruction tuning. On the other hand, results in Table 5 demonstrate
that lengthening the warmup period yields marginal gains in performance, suggesting that the gradient features don’t change
much in the intermediate and late phases of instruction tuning. We emphasize that especially in the case of the cross entropy
objective, it is possible for the gradient features in Definition 3.1 to change substantially even if the model exhibits kernel
behavior. It is thus difficult to relate the loss curves in Figure 5 to the evolution of the empirical neural tangent kernel over
the course of instruction tuning.
Direct verification is too challenging. Kernel behavior is called as such because the dynamics are described by a fixed
|D| × |D| kernel, where each entry contains the inner product of the gradients of the model output with respect to the
parameters for different datapoints. Subtly, this matrix must be constructed for every logit, so the computational cost scales
with the number of classes in the dataset. Past works that instantiate this kernel have focused on vision tasks with relatively
few classes (Arora et al., 2019; Yu et al., 2020a; Wei et al., 2022a) or prompt-based text classification (Malladi et al., 2023),
which only considers a label word for each class in simple downstream tasks. On the other hand, instruction tuning requires a
|V|-dimensional vector of logits from the model, where Vis the vocabulary containing, for example, roughly 32,000tokens.
Additionally, each partial context must be treated as its own input, making |D|the length of each sequence multiplied by the
number of sequences in the dataset. Therefore, computing the kernel for instruction tuning is computationally infeasible,
given the massive size of Dand the large number of output classes.
G. Comparison to Data Models (Ilyas et al., 2022)
Concurrent work in Engstrom et al. (2024) applies the datamodels framework (Ilyas et al., 2022) to select pre-training data to
induce strong performance on target downstream tasks. Fitting a datamodel generally requires repeated training of a model
to fit a mapping between the selected data and the resulting accuracy of the trained model, but Park et al. (2023) reframed
the problem to simulate this repeated training procedure

techniques are inspired by influence functions (Koh & Liang, 2017), which permit counterfactual reasoning over training
(e.g., “what would have happened if I omitted this training datapoint?”). On the other hand, the influence formulation
in Pruthi et al. (2020) can only counterfactually reason over one optimization step at a time, not the entire training procedure.

setting, relates to the considerations and observations reported in this paper.
1.Reframing data selection as optimization : Both works reframe the data selection problem as a straightforward
optimization problem, whereby one chooses data to maximally improve a given metric. This approach is in contrast to
prior works that rely on pre-defined notions of useful data (Gururangan et al., 2020; Chen et al., 2023b) or surface-form
features (Xie et al., 2023b). Instead, both works can be considered efficient approximations of meta-optimization
approaches (Nguyen et al., 2021).
2.Approximating training dynamics : Given the considerable computational cost of training LLMs, both works have
to approximate the training dynamics of the model in order to efficiently estimate the effect of including a datapoint.
LESS relies on the assumption that the first-order approximation of the loss dynamics is accurate, whereas Engstrom
et al. (2024) relies on a first-order approximation of how the model output changes during training. The latter is closer
to the kernel view described in the previous section, though we note that the output used in datamodels generally
involves the margin, which is not well-covered by kernel theory. An implicit assumption of both of these techniques is
that the influences of selected datapoints add linearly (i.e., selecting two equally highly scored datapoints will doubly
improve the model performance). Theory in Saunshi et al. (2023) provides a start at understanding when this linearity
holds, but it may not apply to all settings. For example, in the case where the same datapoint is duplicated in the
training set, we don’t expect a marked improvement from the inclusion of the duplicate.
3.Proxy models and selection models : Both works require performing initial training in a smaller, computationally
efficient setup before performing data selection. Engstrom et al. (2024) trained smaller so-called proxy models to fit
the datamodel, whereas LESS requires a short warmup training period using the selection model in order to compute
the influence in Definition 3.1.
4.Sequence selection versus token selection : In§3.2, we describe how selecting sequences instead of individual tokens
requires an adjustment to the influence formulation. The token versus sequence consideration also appears in Engstrom
et al. (2024), where the method has to average the model output over the entire sequence before using it in the data
model. Because Engstrom et al. (2024) considers the pre-training setting, where all input sequences are of the same
(maximal) length, we cannot be sure if their proposed methodology circumvents the sequence length bias described
in §3.2.
H. Sequence Level Gradients in Instruction Tuning
In Section 3.2, we discussed that sequence level gradients in instruction tuning exhibit odd properties because they are the
average of the token gradients in the completion. In particular, Figure 3 demonstrates that across datasets, the gradient norm
is strongly anti-correlated with the length of the completion. Similarly, Figure 4 shows that the norm of the update ∥Γ∥
(see Definition 3.1) decays rapidly with length. Therefore, using the straightforward inner product formulation in Section 2
would bias LESS to select short sequences for the training dataset. Intuitively, training on only short sequences would
prevent the model from learning to perform long-form generations, as is required for many tasks. Ablation experiments
in Table 13 demonstrate that using inner products for LESS results in a dataset with much shorter sequences. Training on
this dataset induces markedly worse performance than using the cosine similarity and sometimes worse performance than
random selection. Wang et al. (2020) similarly reported that using dot products for data selection in the machine translation
setting was less stable than using cosine similarity.
Importantly, this phenomenon is not a failure of the influence formulation in Section 2. Rather, it suggests that we

I. Loss vs Accuracy
Our motivation in Section 2 is to select datapoints that will most dramatically reduce the validation loss. However, for many
language modeling tasks, it is unclear how minimizing the cross entropy interacts with the task accuracy. In particular, many
complex tasks require the model to generate long-form sequences of text, and it is not clear how well long-form generation
capability correlates with accuracy.
In Figures 6 to 8, we provide evidence across model scales and tasks that the minimizing the validation loss does not always
correspond to increasing the accuracy. A similar phenomenon was observed in Zhou et al. (2023); Tay et al. (2021). Despite
its reliance on the cross entropy loss, LESS boosts accuracy over relevant baselines. Overall, we suggest that optimizing
alternative objectives may yield better accuracy, but we leave exploring such ideas to future work. We note that any objective
function can be substituted into the derivation in Section 2, so the ideas used in developing LESS are easily extensible.
